journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Development of a high-speed two-colour system and its application to in-cylinder diesel combustion temperature and soot measurements with split injections

article-meta.aff: 1Centre for Advanced Powertrain and Fuels, School of Engineering and Design, Brunel University West London, Uxbridge, Middlesex, UK
2School of Engineering and Materials Science, Queen Mary University of London, London, UK
3IC Engines Advanced Laboratory, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy

author-notes.corresp: *Centre for Advanced Powertrain and Fuels, School of Engineering and Design, Brunel University West London, Uxbridge, Middlesex UB8 3PH, UK. email:a.diez@qmul.ac.uk

abstract.p: In the present study, a high-speed two-colour system was developed in order simultaneously to investigate the temporal and spatially resolved flame temperature and soot concentration (the KL factor) in the combustion chamber of a diesel engine during the same engine cycle. The new two-colour system features a high-speed video camera and a high-repetition image intensifier. It is capable of capturing images at a high sampling frequency, so as to allow the possibility of investigating the flame temperature and soot distribution throughout a complete engine cycle. The system was calibrated against a tungsten ribbon lamp and tested on a Ricardo Hydra single-cylinder diesel engine for the in-cylinder diesel combustion temperature and soot diagnostics. Videos of combustion were taken through the optical access to the combustion chamber, and the radiation intensity was correlated with the analysed calibration data. The two-colour method was used to study the influence of the injection timing on the nitrogen oxide and soot emissions and the relation between the time histories of the local flame temperature, the soot concentration (the KL factor), and the exhaust emissions.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The two-colour method was first demonstrated in 1932 by Hottel and Broughton [1] in a search to determine the flame temperature in industrial furnaces. However, it was Uyehara et al. [2] who first introduced the two-colour method to diesel engine diagnostics in 1946. Ahn et al. [3] and Matsui et al. [4–6] enhanced this technique into a quantitative measurement and presented the discrete flame temperature and soot concentration distributions in a diesel engine. The two-colour method is based on optical pyrometry, which in this case is based on the detection of radiation of the soot particles during combustion. Radiation is measured at two different wavelengths from which the so-called apparent temperatures are calculated. From these two temperatures corresponding to the two different wavelengths, the flame temperature and the soot concentration can be estimated. It is important to emphasize that, despite the fact that this method estimates the temperature from the soot, it is generally accepted that the temperature difference between the soot and the surrounding gases is less than 1 K [4–6]. Zhao and Ladommatos [7, 8] produced a guide for the two-colour method, including the theory behind this technique, its calibration, and implementation. This guide ‘standardized’ the method and therefore significant parameter values such as α have generally been accepted since then. The two-colour method has been achieved with many different optical configurations. Using an optical engine of the ‘Bowditch’ design, many researchers [4–6, 9] have employed charge-coupled device (CCD) cameras. These provide a full view of the combustion chamber, but the combustion itself may differ from that in a standard production engine as in-cylinder conditions are difficult to replicate in optical engines. A less interfering way of applying this method consists in using fibre optics [10, 11] or the endoscopic visualization technique [12, 13]. Using a two-stroke optical diesel engine, Tominaga et al. [14] applied this method with a complementary metal–oxide semiconductor (CMOS) high-speed video camera. However, this was done at a very low engine speed, i.e. 345 r/min, and with a recording speed of 1000 frames/s.

In this study, a single-cylinder optical research engine running at a relatively high speed of 2000 r/min was used and the two-colour method was extended to cycle-resolved high-speed flame temperature and soot measurements using a high-speed video camera with a CMOS sensor and a high-repetition image intensifier at a recording speed of 10 000 frames/s. First the underlying theory of this technique, the calibration, its implementation, and the accuracy of the method are presented. Then the application of this newly developed two-colour system to investigate the effect of the injection timing on the combustion temperature and soot distribution is demonstrated and discussed.

sec.title: 2 Two-Colour Theory
sec.p: The soot produced during combustion emits radiation. The two-colour method is based on the measurement of this radiation at two different wavelengths in order to estimate both the flame temperature and the soot concentration. Although the method estimates the flame temperature through the radiation emitted by soot, it is recognized that the temperature difference between the soot and the surrounding gases is only around 1 K [4–6].

Black-body radiation is described by the Planck law which states that the radiation intensity from a black body depends on the temperature of the black body itself at a given wavelength, according to the equation
where
Eb,λ = black-body radiation intensity at the temperature T (W/m3)
λ = wavelength of the radiation
C1 = first Planck constant
C2 = second Planck constant
T = black-body temperature (K)

sec.title: 2.1 Estimation of the flame temperature
sec.p: In the two-colour method, black-body radiation and non-black-body radiation can be correlated by introducing the concept of an apparent temperature Ta and emissivity. Using an empirical correlation developed by Hottel and Broughton [1], and applying this for the two apparent temperatures at different wavelengths λ1 and λ2, if the apparent temperatures Ta1 and Ta2 have been obtained, the flame temperature can be calculated from
where
α1 = alpha value at the wavelength λ1
α2 = alpha value at the wavelength λ2
The apparent temperatures can be estimated prior to two-colour measurement through a calibration system by means of a tungsten calibration lamp. This will be explained in the next section.

sec.title: 2.2 The KL factor and the soot concentration estimation
sec.p: Once the value of the flame temperature T is calculated from equation (1), in order to calculate the value of KL (which is proportional to the concentration of the soot), T is substituted in
where
K = absorption coefficient proportional to the density of soot
L = geometric flame thickness along the optical axis of the detection system

sec.title: 3 Implementation
sec.p: As previously explained, the flame temperature can be estimated using equation (2) for which it is necessary to calculate the apparent temperatures at two different wavelengths and to define the parameter α.

sec.title: 3.1 Selection of the parameter α
sec.p: The estimation of the flame temperature and of the KL factor depends on the choice of a suitable value for α. The α value depends on the light wavelength, on the soot particle size, and on the refractive index of soot. In the selection of α, it is less critical for the flame temperature estimation if the selected wavelengths are in the visible range of the spectra when α = α1 = α2 as shown in Fig. 1. A compilation of the values used for the parameter α in the literature was given in references [7] and [8], which conclude that, for a selection of wavelengths in the visible region, the recommended value of the parameter α is 1.39. Hence, this value has been commonly employed for most previous two-colour measurements [16–18] and was used in the present work.

caption.p: Effect of the parameter α on the estimated flame temperature

sec.title: 3.2 Choice of the wavelengths
sec.p: In the two-colour method, detection at two wavelengths is necessary to solve equation (2). The radiation can be detected in the visible and infrared regions [19, 20]. Visible wavelengths are preferred because the sensitivity of the measuring system to changes in the flame temperature is greater than that in the infrared region. In fact, the rate of change in the spectral radiance with respect to temperature, denoted dλ/dT, is larger in the visible range than in the infrared region (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Spectral radiance of a black body as a function of the temperature

sec.p: During combustion in diesel engines, there is thermal radiation from the soot particles and radiation emissions from gases. Another reason why the visible region is preferable over the infrared region is that, in the infrared region, radiation or absorption from gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO), water vapour, and even fuel vapour can take place.

sec.title: 3.3 High-speed image-recording system
sec.p: The two-colour method application was extended in this study to the use of high-speed video cameras, so as to allow the flame temperature and soot concentration to be estimated for the entire cyclical combustion process. Figure 3 shows the schematic diagram of the high-speed two-colour experimental set-up. Using the Ricardo Hydra engine with optical access of the Bowditch design, the optical set-up consists of a high-speed camera NAC Memerecam FX6000 CMOS camera, a high-repetition image intensifier, and a standard Nikon 60 mm f 2.8 lens. In front of the lens, a mounting block was installed to hold an image doubler where two half-circumference bandpass filters at 550 nm and 750 nm were fitted. As the two-colour method requires capturing two images of combustion, a Hoya Vari-Multivision image doubler and two TFI Technology Inc. bandpass filters were used in this study. The filters were specifically cut into two semicircles in order to be suitable for the image doubler. Their specifications are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the two-colour experimental set-up
Specifications of the bandpass filters

tr.th: Value for the following bandpass filters

fn.p: T, transmission; B, out of band transmission; Tk, thickness.

sec.p: The image intensifier is designed to provide light intensification, high-speed shuttering, and ultraviolet-to-visible conversion for use with a range of high-speed cameras and video systems. It is lens coupled to the high-speed video camera and can operate at high-speed imaging up to approximately 100 000 frames/s. The intensifier is synchronized with the high-speed camera through a bayonet Neill–Concelman (BNC) cable connected to the transistor–transistor logic input signal connector of the high-speed camera.

The spectral emissivity of the system is determined by the spectral responses of the high-speed camera and of the intensifier. Figures 4 and 5 show the spectral responses of these instruments, namely the performances of these instruments at different wavelengths. By adding their performances at the 550 nm and 750 nm wavelengths, it is possible to estimate, for a certain light intensity, the response of the whole system. As can be seen in these figures, the total spectral response of the system at 750 nm is significantly lower than that at 550 nm. Thus, two Kodak Warren neutral density filters with 10 per cent transmission were used in front of the 550 nm bandpass filter to reduce its radiation intensity so that the intensities at both 550 nm and 750 nm had similar values.

caption.p: Spectral response of the high-speed camera
Spectral response of the intensifier

sec.title: 3.4 Recording high-speed images
sec.p: As for the combustion imaging, the high-speed camera is manually triggered when the engine is firing, so as to allow several cycles to be recorded. The intensifier is then triggered externally by the high-speed camera via a BNC cable. The high-speed camera records a movie of combustion at a rate of 10 000 frames/s. Each frame is then processed in order to estimate the flame temperature and the KL factor (the image-processing method is explained in the following sections). Finally, all the frames are put together to make up the flame temperature and KL factor movies.

sec.title: 4 Calibration
sec.p: The two-colour method is based on the estimation of two apparent temperatures. After calculating these apparent temperatures, the KL factor and the flame temperature can be estimated. With this set-up, every frame is analysed pixel by pixel, giving intensity values. Hence, the system must be calibrated so that the pixel values correspond to the apparent temperatures. This calibration can be performed using a black body, and a calibration curve can be obtained for the two selected wavelengths.

Tungsten ribbon and black-body lamps are standard sources of thermal radiation. As a black body was not available, a tungsten ribbon lamp was used as a source of thermal radiation. The lamp was calibrated in terms of the apparent temperature and the supplied current (Fig. 6).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the set-up for the two-colour calibration with a tungsten lamp

sec.p: This calibration set-up mimics that used in the single-cylinder optical engine for the experiments. A 45° mirror is applied to simulate the mirror under the glass piston window and a transparent piston window is placed in front of the lamp, with exactly the same layout as in the single-cylinder engine.

The tungsten lamp was calibrated by the manufacturer against a standard black body and this was carried out at a wavelength of 660 nm. However, in order to calculate the apparent temperatures at 550 nm and 750 nm, the emissivity values at these wavelengths were required, as given below by equation (4). Larrabee [21] proposed the relationship between the apparent temperature and emissivity of tungsten, as shown in Table 2. For the wavelengths of 550 nm and 750 nm, the emissivity values were obtained by interpolation: for the wavelength of 550 nm, from those at 540 nm and 560 nm; for the wavelength of 750 nm, from those at 740 nm and 760 nm. More specifically, from these emissivity values, the apparent temperatures were calculated as

A relationship was found between the red–green–blue colour intensity pixel values of the frames and the apparent temperatures, as shown in Fig. 7 for the two apparent temperatures Ta1 and Ta2, calculated at the wavelengths of 550 nm and 750 nm respectively.

caption.p: Emissivity table
Calibration curves for the f2.8 lens with an intensifier gain of 65 per cent

sec.p: Although the flame temperature and the soot concentration (the KL factor) were calculated on a pixel-by-pixel basis, the calibration using the tungsten ribbon was carried out on an average sensitivity of the array. The reason for this is that the array area for the calibration and the area of the combustion images were very similar and located in the centre of the array, as seen in Fig. 8. It was assumed consequently that the pixel-to-pixel intensity was constant in that centre part of the CMOS sensor.

caption.p: One combustion and one calibration frame

sec.p: The high-speed camera was set to take movies with 30 frames for every calibration point; the pixel values were averaged over them. During this calibration procedure, it was found that, at low apparent temperatures, the difference between the pixel values of the frames was extremely high owing to the low signal-to-noise ratio. However, as the apparent temperatures increased, the difference decreased. As a consequence of this, the calibration error trends were inversely proportional to the temperature of the tungsten ribbon lamp, as is shown in Fig. 9.

caption.p: Calibration error dependence on the temperature

sec.p: For each different setting of the shutter lens position and intensifier gain, a cut-off pixel value was introduced in the relationship between the apparent temperature and the pixel values, below which the apparent temperature was conventionally considered to be zero. By using these cut-off values, the error in the averaged intensity values for the 30 frames selected for every calibration was less than 5 per cent (Fig. 9). As a result, the first few frames just after the start of combustion and the last few frames of combustion were not analysed, and thus it was not possible to include these apparent flame temperatures and the KL factors in the movies of the flame temperature and KL factor.

The movies taken with the high-speed camera show two images of combustion. These images correspond to two different wavelengths and, therefore, to two apparent temperatures. Using equations (2) and (3), each frame of the movie was processed using LabVIEW and then the flame temperature and the KL factor were estimated. These were both displayed as contour maps.

sec.title: 5 Accuracy
sec.p: In order to assess the accuracy of the method, there are several factors that have to be taken into account.

sec.title: 5.1 Soot deposition on the window
sec.p: When running the engine, soot accumulates on the observation window, reducing the radiation transmissivity. This can negatively affect the flame temperature and the soot concentration measurements. The soot concentration is affected in a higher proportion than is the flame temperature. This occurs because the KL factor is directly proportional to the absolute amount of radiation, whereas the flame temperature is determined mainly by the radiation ratio at the two wavelengths. In order to minimize the soot deposition effects, the window was cleaned after every single test, although no soot deposition signals were observed between the tests.

sec.title: 5.2 Use of bandpass filters
sec.p: The bandpass filters used in this study both have a full width at half-maximum of 40 nm. The radiation is dependent on the temperature and the wavelength, as the temperature increases; changes in the wavelength have a greater effect. Thus, for a wavelength difference of 40 nm at a temperature of 2500 K, the radiation could vary up to 5 per cent.

sec.title: 5.3 Wall reflections
sec.p: The two-colour system detects the radiation from the soot and the gaseous substances. Although it also detects the radiation reflected off the walls or the thermal radiation by the cylinder walls, this can be ignored in the visible region because the temperatures of the wall surfaces are much lower than the temperatures of the soot particles (Fig. 3).

sec.title: 6 Results of high-speed two-colour measurements
sec.p: In recent years, diesel engines have become a very important part of the automotive industry. However, owing to the increasingly stringent regulations, automotive research has been focused on reducing the emissions of pollutants in vehicles, and in particular the emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and soot in diesel engines. The flexibility in the injection system has made it possible for researchers to investigate combustion modes which are different from conventional diesel combustion to achieve diesel com-bustion reducing the NOx and soot emissions simultaneously. Although split-injection strategies have been investigated previously, limited in-cylinder investigations have been conducted using a split-injection strategy with high levels of exhaust gas recirculation (EGR). EGR has been proven to be responsible for the NOx reduction in diesel engines. In addition, split-injection strategies, where the first injection quantity is higher than the second injection quantity, have shown a potential to reduce the soot emissions because of improvement in the mixing process.

The two-colour method was employed as part of this study to investigate the influence of the injection timing on NOx and soot emissions and the relation between the flame temperature and the KL factor with the exhaust emissions.

All experimental testing in this study was completed on a single-cylinder Ricardo Hydra engine, designed to be representative of a typical modern high-speed direct-injection diesel engine. The engine consists of a Ricardo Hydra crankcase, an extended cylinder block, and a cylinder head from a production four-cylinder engine and is equipped with a common-rail fuel injection system. The injector used for this study was a Delphi injector of the microsac nozzle design. The engine specifications are detailed in Table 3.

caption.p: Engine specifications

sec.p: Five different injection timings for the same 10 ° dwell angle split injection were investigated in part-load operating conditions at 2000 r/min with a high EGR level (60 per cent). The matrix of the experiments as well as the indicated mean effective pressure (IMEP) obtained for each injection timing are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Experimental matrix and the IMEP values

sec.p: For the strategies analysed, the cylinder pressure data were recorded. The heat release rate was calculated using the one-zone model, considering the gases within the cylinder as homogeneous (without distinguishing between burned and unburned gases), and the energy generated from the combustion process as a separate additional source of energy. The first law of thermodynamics is applied to the combustion chamber which is taken as an open system.

Gaseous emissions and soot measurements were also carried out to assess the effect on the performances and emissions of different injection strategies. The exhaust emissions measurements of CO, CO2, oxygen (O2), unburned hydrocarbons, nitric oxide (NO), and NOx were made using a Horiba MEXA-7170DEGR analyser system, and soot emissions were measured using an AVL 415 smoke meter.

Figure 10 shows the cylinder pressure traces and heat release rate curves versus the crank angle (CA) after top dead centre (ATDC) for the five injection timings investigated in this study. The heat release rate curves show a gradual decrease until fuel injection takes place; this is probably due to blow-by, as some gas can flow past the piston rings or between the graphite gasket fitted between the window and the upper piston. From the heat release rate curves, it can be seen that the first two injection timings show a high premixed combustion peak followed by a slow mixing-controlled combustion phase. As the injection timing is retarded, the ignition delay is shortened and, therefore, there is less fuel available to burn in the premixed phase (the peak cylinder pressure is reduced). The curve of the heat release rate shows more diffusion combustion in the most retarded cases when combustion starts at several CAs ATDC. As a result, the combustion temperatures are expected to be lower and, hence, also the NOx emissions are lower, as seen in Table 5. Similarly the increase in the diffusion combustion phase could lead to an increase in the soot emissions, as shown in Table 5.

caption.p: Cylinder pressure and heat release rate for split-injection strategies
Exhaust emissions

sec.p: Figure 11 presents the combustion images obtained for the first-injection timing strategy. The first flames are observed at 3.6° CA BTDC, in accordance with the heat release rate data. It can be seen that ignition sites appear slightly downstream of the spray tips in the direction of in-cylinder swirl motion and expand to larger regions, indicating good fuel–air mixture. The first frames show the low luminosity typical of premixed combustion and, as combustion continues, there are small areas with high luminosity, which are caused by the burning of soot particles formed in the fuel-rich diffusion combustion. In the next few frames, the combustion regions follow the in-cylinder swirl motion, and the intensities of the luminous regions decrease.

caption.p: Combustion images for test 1: frames from 3.6° CA before top dead centre (BTDC) to top dead centre (TDC) to 21.6° CA ATDC

sec.p: Figures 12 and 13 show the sequences of the flame temperature and the KL factor images for the injection timing test 1. In the flame temperature images, it can be seen that there are four main points where the flame temperature is high, reaching 2500 K, which last until 4.8° CA ATDC. corresponding to the peak of the premixed combustion. From there onwards, the temperature is reduced. During the premixed combustion, NOx is produced in the high-temperature regions; therefore, it could be expected that some NOx is emitted in the exhaust emissions, as indicated by the exhaust NOx emissions which are relatively higher than in the other cases but are still significantly lower than in conventional diesel combustion. Looking at the KL factor images, it can be noticed that very little soot is produced in the early stages of combustion and more soot is formed during the diffusion combustion phase. As this strategy has the largest premixed combustion phase, it should be expected that the lowest soot levels are measured in the exhaust, which agrees with the data shown in Table 5.

caption.p: Flame temperatures for test 1: frames from 1.2° CA BTDC to 12.0° CA ATDC
KL factors for test 1: frames from 1.2° CA BTDC to 12.0° CA ATDC

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the sequence of images for the injection timing test 3, while Fig. 15 illustrates the flame temperature images, and the KL factor images appear in Fig. 16. As the injection timing is retarded, the premixed combustion phase is reduced and more fuel burns in the diffusion combustion phase. It can be seen in Fig. 16 that the amount of soot formed in this strategy in considerable higher than in the first strategy.

caption.p: Combustion images for test 3: frames from TDC to 25.2° CA ATDC
Flame temperatures for test 3: frames from 1.2° CA ATDC to 19.2° CA ATDC
KL factors for test 3: frames from 1.2° CA ATDC to 19.2° CA ATDC

sec.p: Figure 17 illustrates the combustion images for the injection timing test 5. According to the sequence of images, it can be seen that premixed combustion takes place uniformly and is distributed close to the cylinder walls. At 12° CA ATDC, the luminosity of the flames is higher than that during the premixed combustion. At this stage the diffusion combustion is predominant and its luminosity is due to the soot radiation. Figures 18 and 19 present the flame temperature and KL factor images respectively for the injection timing test 5. It can be seen that combustion takes place near the cylinder walls and also that there are some points at which the temperature is around 2250 K, while the rest of the flame is at a lower temperature. At 12° CA ATDC, which is after the peak heat release rate, the temperatures of the hot spots have decreased. From 14.4° CA ATDC, the flame temperature of diffusion combustion remains below 2000 K until the end of combustion, hence resulting in the lowest NOx emissions, as seen in Table 5. As shown by the KL factor images in Fig. 19, at 7.2° CA ATDC when premixed combustion takes place, there is a very low concentration of soot at the tip of the leading spray. The last frames show quite a high soot concentration as a result of slower soot oxidation at the lower combustion temperature, leading to increase in the soot emissions, as shown in Table 5.

caption.p: Combustion images for test 5: frames from 3.6° CA ATDC to 27.6° CA ATDC
Flame temperatures for test 5: frames from 6.0° CA ATDC to 19.2° CA ATDC
KL factors for test 5: frames from 6.0° CA ATDC to 19.2° CA ATDC

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: One of the optical techniques commonly applied in engines is called the two-colour method. It has been applied with intensified CCD cameras owing to their high spectral response within a wide range of wavelengths. However, the main drawback of using this type of camera is that, because of the image-processing time of the camera, the images obtained are separated by many cycles. During this investigation, this method was extended and successfully implemented for high-speed imaging to obtain cyclic resolved in-cylinder soot and combustion temperature measurements in a single-cylinder optical engine. The application of this method could be an important tool for combustion modes where cycle-to-cycle variations may be higher than in conventional combustion

This paper has included the theory underlying the technique and procedure for capturing the radiance emitted by soot particles during combustion and its subsequent conversion into the flame temperature and the soot concentration. It also described the implementation of this technique for the use of a high-speed camera to obtain cyclic resolved in-cylinder soot and combustion temperature measurements in a single-cylinder optical engine.

The method has been applied in a study using the split-injection strategy with a high level of EGR in an attempt to reduce NOx and soot emissions simultaneously; the split-injection strategy was adopted in order to promote not only mixing of the fuel–air mixture but also oxidation of the soot particles formed early in the first injection through the momentum of the second fuel injection jet. All strategies have shown similar IMEP values with quite low exhaust emissions values in general. For this dwell angle, air–fuel mixing improves; therefore, more fuel is burned and the much leaner flames lead to this reduction in the emissions. This is confirmed by the combustion images in which the combustion sites spread over almost the complete circumference of the cylinder. NOx emissions are lower than in conventional diesel combustion while also there are relatively low particulate matter emissions. As the injection timing is retarded, the NOx emissions are further decreased with the disadvantage of an increase in the particulate matter emissions. The results obtained agreed with the exhaust emissions values and, thus, the effects of the injection timing on fuel–air mixing, combustion, soot formation, and emission were identified and discussed.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
